title: Use after free in smtp_server_connection_handle_command

profile.name: Open-Xchange
profile.about: Messaging, collaboration and office productivity software for service providers

vulnerability_information:
Function `smtp_server_connection_handle_command` in src/lib-smtp/smtp-server-connection.c creates a variable named cmd with
`cmd = smtp_server_command_new(tmp_conn, cmd_name, cmd_params);`
It gets used with `return (cmd == NULL || !cmd->input_locked);` ie `cmd->input_locked` dereferences the pointer 
But we can get to this code with cmd != NULL and cmd was freed

To do so, we can trigger in `smtp_server_command_submit_reply` the condition
`if (conn != NULL && conn->bad_counter > conn->set.max_bad_commands) {` which calls `smtp_server_connection_terminate` which ends up freeing cmd (`smtp_server_connection_close`, `smtp_server_connection_disconnect`, `smtp_server_command_unref`)
To do so, it is enough do send enough linefeeds characters like "\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n" to the server.

To me the flawed logic is to have the check `if (!smtp_server_connection_unref(&tmp_conn)) {`
This decreases reference count only once, which has been increased before at least twice in `smtp_server_connection_handle_command` and its caller `smtp_server_connection_input`

Proposed patch is
```
diff --git a/src/lib-smtp/smtp-server-connection.c b/src/lib-smtp/smtp-server-connection.c
index 404acc888b..ab8746fb2b 100644
--- a/src/lib-smtp/smtp-server-connection.c
+++ b/src/lib-smtp/smtp-server-connection.c
@@ -295,8 +295,10 @@ smtp_server_connection_handle_command(struct smtp_server_connection *conn,
        struct smtp_server_command *cmd;
 
        smtp_server_connection_ref(tmp_conn);
+       int refcount = tmp_conn->refcount;
        cmd = smtp_server_command_new(tmp_conn, cmd_name, cmd_params);
-       if (!smtp_server_connection_unref(&tmp_conn)) {
+       if (refcount > tmp_conn->refcount ||
+               !smtp_server_connection_unref(&tmp_conn)) {
                /* the command start callback managed to get this connection
                   destroyed */
                return FALSE;
```

This was found by fuzzing

## Impact

The attacker can use this as a denial of service against the SMTP server.

activities.message:
Hi!

Thank you for the report, we will look into this.

Hi!

Were you able to actually get a crash?

Hi!

Thanks for the quick feedback.

I managed to get a crash with my fuzz target, compiled with Address Sanitizer (ASAN).
I did not manage to find how to run dovecot as a SMTP server (and thus unable to make it crash).
Can you give me some pointers on how to do this ? Should I run lmtp binary ?

Do you want me to share the fuzz target here ?
It is inspired by the smtp server tests

Here is some excerpts from the stack trace :
```
==2067==ERROR: AddressSanitizer: heap-use-after-free on address 0x6190020e1948 at pc 0x000101039353 bp 0x7ffeeec44af0 sp 0x7ffeeec44ae8
READ of size 1 at 0x6190020e1948 thread T0
    #0 0x101039352 in smtp_server_connection_handle_command smtp-server-connection.c:309
    #1 0x1010384c3 in smtp_server_connection_handle_input smtp-server-connection.c:432
    #2 0x101037e2a in smtp_server_connection_input smtp-server-connection.c:581
    #3 0x1010c17ab in io_loop_call_io ioloop.c:713
    #4 0x1010c2990 in io_loop_call_pending ioloop.c:751
    #5 0x1010c2469 in io_loop_handler_run ioloop.c:766
    #6 0x1010c20ed in io_loop_run ioloop.c:738
    #7 0x100fbaed1 in LLVMFuzzerTestOneInput fuzz-smtp-server.c:86

0x6190020e1948 is located 200 bytes inside of 1024-byte region [0x6190020e1880,0x6190020e1c80)
freed by thread T0 here:
    #0 0x1013ee10d in wrap_free (libclang_rt.asan_osx_dynamic.dylib:x86_64h+0x5710d)
    #1 0x10102489a in smtp_server_command_unref smtp-server-command.c:303
    #2 0x101032761 in smtp_server_connection_disconnect smtp-server-connection.c:1060
    #3 0x10102fe34 in smtp_server_connection_close smtp-server-connection.c:1289
    #4 0x10103433e in smtp_server_connection_terminate smtp-server-connection.c:1315
    #5 0x101026976 in smtp_server_command_submit_reply smtp-server-command.c:573
    #6 0x101023fd4 in smtp_server_command_fail smtp-server-command.c:720
    #7 0x101023a71 in smtp_server_command_new smtp-server-command.c
    #8 0x1010391e2 in smtp_server_connection_handle_command smtp-server-connection.c:298
    #9 0x1010384c3 in smtp_server_connection_handle_input smtp-server-connection.c:432
    #10 0x101037e2a in smtp_server_connection_input smtp-server-connection.c:581
    #11 0x1010c17ab in io_loop_call_io ioloop.c:713
    #12 0x1010c2990 in io_loop_call_pending ioloop.c:751
    #13 0x1010c2469 in io_loop_handler_run ioloop.c:766
    #14 0x1010c20ed in io_loop_run ioloop.c:738
    #15 0x100fbaed1 in LLVMFuzzerTestOneInput fuzz-smtp-server.c:86
```

I had first found the bug fixed by https://github.com/dovecot/core/commit/429756095dde22eca7085d91f7047b013d866f22
So, I guessed I was on the right path.
Then I rebased on latest commit from today.

Another obvious fix for a null pointer dereference is 
```
diff --git a/src/lib-smtp/smtp-syntax.c b/src/lib-smtp/smtp-syntax.c
index 5d22445f72..43db157ded 100644
--- a/src/lib-smtp/smtp-syntax.c
+++ b/src/lib-smtp/smtp-syntax.c
@@ -32,7 +32,8 @@ int smtp_string_parse(const char *string,
                return -1;
        }
        if (parser.cur < parser.end) {
-               *error_r = "Invalid character in string";
+               if (error_r != NULL)
+                       *error_r = "Invalid character in string";
                return -1;
        }
        return 1;
``

You can use following to start dovecot submission server for crash reproduction

```
protocols = submission

mail_home=/srv/mail/%Lu
mail_location=sdbox:~/Mail

# if you want to use system users
passdb {
  driver = static
  args = password=pass
}

ssl=no
```

If you want to do post-login testing, you need to add

```
submission_relay_host=some.mx.server
```

I was able to reproduce the invalid memory access with submission-login and valgrind using external input. No crash though. I cannot rule out crash, but it does seem that the availability score migth be too high for this issue.

Thanks for the tips and for managing to reproduce this.

Indeed, the result of a use-after-free depends on many things : operating system, compile options, time (and use of memory) between the free and the use (I do not think there is any allocation done in this spot here)
Anyways, it is up to you to score how high you rate this issue :-)

Should I submit another report for the null pointer dereference in `smtp_string_parse` ?
Thank you for the excellent report.
Do you have preference on how to credit you on this issue and the other?

You can credit this as :
Philippe Antoine (Catena cyber)

PS : I have another null dereference coming up (investigating the right fix)
Hi! Just to let you know that this is being published in about two months along with the other one.
